page.title: 02The Countryside in Aith
page.content: Most of the land area in our block is rough moorland. The soil beneath is peaty and the cover is rough grass and heather. This provides habitat for a number of animals birds and insects. The moorland is used as rough grazing for sheep, though increasingly areas of it are being reseeded to provide better quality grazing. The more arable land is in the lower areas close to the sea. Most of this land is used in crofting, either as grazing or for crops. The road verges and small areas of unused land support many varieties of wild flowers. There are a number of lochs in the area and burns run down into Aith Voe and East Burrafirth. The Loch of Houster is noted as a site for wintering wild fowl. The area is virtually treeless.
